channel.title: Bachya Productions
channel.description: Welcome to Bachya Productions, a blog about life, God, technology, and other musings by Aaron Bach.

item.title: Link Mash (July 23, 2015)
item.description:
The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • A Two-Context Approach to GTD with OmniFocus. Not sure about this, but it’s wild enough to consider.
  • How I Use Due 2 – Come With Me If You Want To Live. A very interesting idea, but to be honest, I just haven’t been able to make Due work for me. I’m just not a fan of constant reminders going off.
  • Dune, 50 years on: how a science fiction novel changed the world. I didn’t get Dune when I first read it 10-12 years ago. Since then, I’ve come to regard this story for what it truly is: a classic.

This Link Mash was generated by PinPress, a simple tool to generate text templates from Pinboard data.

item.title: Link Mash (June 18, 2015)
item.description:
The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • jlevy/the-art-of-command-line. “the-art-of-command-line – Master the command line, in one page.” Such a handy reference!
  • Here’s The First Actual Gameplay Footage Of Star Wars Battlefront | TechCrunch. I LITERALLY CANNOT WAIT.
  • How to Force an MSI Package to Install Using Administrator Mode. Installing an MSI under Administrator privileges is such a hassle; leave it to the HowTo Geek to make my life easier.
  • airbnb/javascript · GitHub. “A mostly reasonable approach to JavaScript.” Another wonderfully handy reference.
  • US DOLLAR REDESIGN PROJECT on Behance. This may be a pipe dream, but I think U.S. currency is long overdue for a refresh.
  • blackbox/README.md at master · StackExchange/blackbox. A great means to store secure information in an otherwise “other-person-accessible” Git repository.
  • what3words | Addressing the world. “what3words is a giant grid comprised of 57 trillion 3m x 3m squares that cover the entire globe. It is the simplest way to communicate location.”

This Link Mash was generated by PinPress, a simple tool to generate text templates from Pinboard data.

item.title: Link Mash (April 2, 2015)
item.description:
The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • TIE Fighter Short Film. So, so cool.
  • Rockin’ OmniFocus Templates on iOS. Creating a copy of an OmniFocus project should be so much easier on iOS; at least this workaround exists.
  • **A Fresh Take on Contexts. **Because my life isn’t going anywhere unless I’m thinking about GTD contexts.

item.title: Link Mash (March 5, 2015)
item.description:
The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • Tap for Beats Per Minute BPM. A great little tool to manually determine a song’s BPM
  • Time Sensitive Dropbox Shared Links — There’s a Workflow for That. This is a great OS X abs iOS workflow that solves a common problem.
  • The Tommy Westphall Universe. This is the most unbelievable thing I’ve ever seen.
  • Over 2,400 MS-DOS Games — Like Oregon Trail — Can Now Be Played Online. You’ve already seen this, I’m sure…but in case not, WOW.
  • Understanding the Bible 55: Conclusion – The Tree of Life… — Jesus at 2AM | A Humorous, Intelligent Introduction to the Bible, Theology, Church History & the Spiritual Life — Overcast. This is one of the greatest, most concise explanations of all of Scripture that I’ve ever heard.

item.title: Link Mash (December 31, 2015)
item.description:
The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • 7 TextExpander Macros to Increase Your Typing Efficiency. I really appreciate the time-sensitive salutations. I’ve even developed one for my team in India; if I simply type “;isal”, it spits out “Good morning/afternoon/evening” depending on their timezone.
  • deanishe/alfred-workflow · GitHub. A supremely helpful Python library for building rich Alfred workflows.
  • OmniFocus project templates on iOS – SimplicityBliss. Leave it to Sven Fechner to solve a common OmniFocus for iOS problem – creating instances of “template” projects – in an intriguing way. I use this for things like packing lists.

This Link Mash was generated by PinPress, a simple tool to generate text templates from Pinboard data.

item.title: Managing LastPass with Alfred 2
item.description:
I recently realized a gross inefficiency in my life: managing my LastPass vault. You’ll no doubt know of LastPass, the excellent cross-platform password manager.

It’s a wonderful tool and I love it dearly. However, it’s a tale of two experiences for me. When it comes to auto-logging-in to websites (LastPass’ original, intended purpose) it works beautifully; however, when it comes to copying passwords/usernames/etc. out of the vault (for, say, the purpose of pasting them into applications that don’t support a LastPass integration, like nearly every iOS app), it’s a pain.

The pain comes from the fact that I have to:

  1. open my browser.
  2. click on the LastPass extension.
  3. enter my master password.
  4. click on the extension again.
  5. search for my site.
  6. copy my desired info.

The amount of friction is nauseating. Therefore, I set out to build something better.

TL;DR

LP Vault Manager is an Alfred 2 workflow designed to manipulate a LastPass vault.

The Tools

Alfred is one of my champions when it comes to quick, easy, time-saving, productivity-boosting workflows.  It popped to mind as an obvious choice for easier, more frictionless interaction with LastPass. Additionally, LastPass stepped up their game in October by releasing an open-source command line app to interact with a LastPass vault.

Combine these two together with some flourish and style and you get…

LP Vault Manager

Direct Download

Open on Github

Open on Packal

Introducing LP Vault Manager, an Alfred workflow designed to manipulate and interact with a LastPass vault. Currently, the workflow supports the following functionality:

  • Search a LastPass vault for items.
  • Instantly launch a vault item in the default browser.
  • Copy a vault item’s username and password.
  • Randomly generate a configurable number of passwords.

Instructions on how to use the workflow can be found in the GitHub repo. I am planning more functionality, but I would love to hear what the community would like. Join the discussion on the Alfred forum or get your hands dirty and jump into the repo itself.

Enjoy!

item.title: Link Mash (December 11, 2014)
item.description:
The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • Variable Handwritting. SO COOL.
  • Getting Started with JavaScript for Automation on Yosemite. A great into to scripting with JavaScript on Yosemite.
  • Artist Recreates Memorable Moments of Final Fantasy VII. So cool. Takes me down memory lane.
  • GTD in 15 minutes – A Pragmatic Guide to Getting Things Done. One of the best, most concise descriptions of GTD that I’ve seen. Best of all is the opening quote: “Pretend your brain is a white board. Is it covered with to-do lists and ‘DO NOT ERASE’? Is there space for drawing and combining ideas?”

This Link Mash was generated by PinPress, a simple tool to generate text templates from Pinboard data.

item.title: Link Mash (November 13, 2014)
item.description:
The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • Slated Is an iOS Keyboard that Automatically Translates What You Type. It’s amazing that not long ago, this thpe of thing would have been impossible on iOS.
  • This Graphic Offers Good-Looking Fonts to Replace Dull, Overused Ones. A great look at some alternatives to common fonts.
  • My favorite iOS 8 features, big and small. I can’t believe I didn’t know some of these.
  • Why We Still Need URL Schemes When iOS 8 Brings the Sharing Dialog to Every App?. It’s true: although we’ll continue to keep it around, the golden age of URL schemes has passed.
  • Public Data Sets : Amazon Web Services. Because having huge public data sets to play around with is never a bad thing. (via Tim Hopper)

This Link Mash was generated by PinPress, a simple tool to generate text templates from Pinboard data.

item.description:
The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.
